True crime: What is all of the fuss about?

17/10/2022

Henry Gee investigates our obsession with the macabre through a scepticâ€™s lens

Image by Cottonbro

By Hannah Carley

I didnâ€™t know anything about true crime, but now I think I know too much. Went too far down the rabbit role, got too close, became too involved; and Iâ€™ve been staring at that asinine phrase for far too long.

â€œTrue Crimeâ€. It doesnâ€™t make sense anymore. What does it even mean? I understand what crime is (hint: itâ€™s crimes). I think true is perhaps the stickler. Maybe true means real. These crimes actually happened, they involve real people and real outcomes. Fictional crimes donâ€™t. Unless they are fictionalised accounts of real crimes, in which case they actually happened, but not exactly as told to us. Yet they focus on the same details a true crime show would. If both are the same, then both are real?

Maybe true means accurate. No stone unturned; every detail given as much importance as the next, and each detail â€˜truerâ€™ than the next. Unless most of the details are sleuthed from Wikipedia, which some podcast hosts readily admit to. Speculation also comes with the territory. Part of the fun no doubt, but also very much not accurate.

Maybe true means honest. We give you the facts of the crime; the context, the motives, all the players involved. We give you the honesty of our opinion, and we give you the honesty of our reaction. Wince when you wince, gasp when you gasp, recoil when you recoil. Laugh when you laugh? Why is everyone so obsessed? It just doesnâ€™t make any sense.

History lesson. Our current fascination and obsession with true crime is nothing new. For as long as we have been committing horrific acts against one another, we have been regaling detailed tales of
those horrific acts. Bards, professional story-tellers, would travel kingdom to kingdom singing and poeting about wars, myths, and local history. Not necessarily true, or crime-like, but these stories had to draw from something. Sure, Beowulf and Grendel arenâ€™t real, but the conflicts within the tale, and
the graphic details, are.

With regards to the telling of local histories, yes they were partly there to placate the current ruler, profess them to be the best and part of a long lineage of other rulers being the best, but they also create a sense of shared belonging. You are part of these stories and this history even if you were not physically there. The violence and gory details are window dressing for reinforcing communal belonging.

The invention and success of the printing press gave rise to journalism. Short pamphlets would be sold in towns and cities containing reports and details of local crimes and murders. These had, because of course they did, a lesson to be learnt. Horrific acts are committed by sinners, who earn eternal damnation. Wouldnâ€™t want to end up like them, would you? Donâ€™t do bad crime! Needless to say, these pamphlets were very popular.

As printing becomes cheaper, more people are reading papers and books, and more eyes need to be kept on the page. Regaling of such crimes no longer becomes about punitive measures, but simply to sell papers and turn a profit. Nothing sells like a scandal. Or more specifically, nothing sells like continued speculation about a scandal; whatâ€™s more scandalous than a murder?

The â€˜Jack the Ripperâ€™ coverage perfectly exemplifies this. Not only was there extensive, detailed coverage of the murders, but also rampant and fractured speculation on the motivation of the killings and the identity of the killer. There was the â€˜mother issues campâ€™. The â€˜heâ€™s Irish campâ€™. The â€˜heâ€™s really the grandson of Queen Victoria camp. Different factions of people were built around shared beliefs about how to interpret the murders, all given importance and influenced by the blanket coverage. The public were not simply passively reading about these crimes any more, but actively involving themselves in the speculating and reporting.

Even so, a report in a newspaper is very different from the kind of true crime shows we have today. A newspaper is simply a reporting of the facts. Shows have to tell a story. Many point to Truman Capoteâ€™s â€˜In Cold Bloodâ€™, a non-fiction novel that documented the murders of the Clutter Family and subsequent fallout, as being the instance where these two aspects of true crime were crystalised. It wasnâ€™t the first, but it was certainly the best. With its combination of fervent, analytical, investigative detail of a newspaper, and the personal, idiosyncratic style of a novel, it gave readers the story of the murders, the feeling of the murders, not simply the facts. It was a huge success, read by nearly everyone in the US as the time. It made Capote incredibly famous. Already a household name, he became a namier-name in housier-holds. A talk show staple. A personality. A blueprint. Readers could now interpret and theorise about two things; the crime and the teller.

Add to this blueprint the internet and social media, which fundamentally changed the way we share media and content. Then again we add the iPod and smart phone, which fundamentally changed the way we consume media and content. This brings us to where we are today; personality driven, detailed, sometimes investigative, shows about crime (but mostly murders).

Now, as I admitted at the start, I knew very little about true crime and never really liked the few shows I did come across, but I realise Iâ€™m firmly in the minority with that opinion. Most of my friends and family enjoy some form of true crime. A few are simply freaks who enjoy the macabre; consuming only the goriest and darkest stuff. Constantly having to one up themselves in gruesomeness, they live in constant fear that one day they might take matters into their own hands, and end up in the mouth of the host of their favourite show.

Most, however, are drawn not to the nature of the crimes, though that doesnâ€™t hurt, but to the hosts of the shows. Most murders follow similar patterns which become dull after hundreds and hundreds of episodes. So it falls to the hosts, with their reactions, banter, and general personalities that keep people coming back; making something that would otherwise become rote and stale, interesting and engaging. Watchable. Friendly. Consumable.

Hosts both guide and mimic the reactions of the audience. A good sitcom will make you laugh when youâ€™re supposed to, but a laugh-track never hurt nobody. By mimicking their audiencesâ€™ reactions, hosts affirm a sense of familiarity and community, much like orators of old. You get the in-jokes, you understand their reactions; it creates a reality with which you are familiar and feel
safe within.

Jacques Lacan; controversial philosopher, Frenchman, someone to bring up at parties you donâ€™t mind getting kicked out of, says that â€˜realityâ€™ exists at three levels. An individual level; what we wear, personal politics, the identity we create for ourselves. A social level; the habits and expectations installed in and on us by cultural norms. And finally, a third level, where the previous two are disrupted and removed entirely; reality without being told what to be. Itâ€™s why after traumatic events the first thing we ask is â€œwhy, what happened?â€. Weâ€™re trying to explain and give reason to the trauma we just experienced. Reinstate the individual and social levels of reality. Make it so that the unknown becomes
known and understandable.

True crime provides both a disrupting and a reinstating of social and individual ways of being. In highlighting the horrific, they invite questions as to the fragility of the â€˜realitiesâ€™ weâ€™ve created for ourselves and others. To murder is to transgress these boundaries, to disrupt our â€˜reality; itâ€™s an act of trauma. Hearing about these acts is traumatic. But in reacting as the audience would, by guiding their reaction through storytelling, phrasing, empathy, they lead us back to a social reality that shields us from these traumatic, transgressive events. It gives them meaning and reason. Even unsolved cases or random acts of violence can be explained. Laying out the detailed specifics, giving them a place and a context; the murder may be unsolved, we now collectively understand why. Why is it weâ€™re so
obsessed? Because weâ€™re not watching or listening to be scared, we do it to feel safe.

That being said, I think as true crime became more popular, and the market oversaturated, it lost
something about what drew so many people in. It became corporate, it became formulaic, it became â€˜un-trueâ€™. Friends talking about whatever true crime story they wanted recording in wardrobes into their phones, becomes about stories our market research indicates will generate the most â€˜buzzâ€™ recorded in proper studios. Fans, to creators, to business-people. Like newspapers before them, that want for explanation and sense of community is exploited and used to sell more ad space. I guess the real true crime was putting all our eggs in the neo-liberal basket. Now sponsored by SquareSpace.

I donâ€™t know. Is that really the final conclusion? Huh, I guess I still donâ€™t know anything
about true crime.
